entityx.name: EntityX
entityx.author: @alecthomas
entityx.description: Entity Component Systems (ECS) are a form of decomposition that completely decouples entity logic and data from the entity "objects" themselves. The Evolve your Hierarchy article provides a solid overview of EC systems and why you should use them.

entt.name: EnTT
entt.author: @skypjack
entt.description: EnTT is a header-only, tiny and easy to use library for game programming and much more written in modern C++.

entt (runtime).author: @skypjack
entt (runtime).description: EnTT is a header-only, tiny and easy to use library for game programming and much more written in modern C++.

ginseng.name: Ginseng
ginseng.author: @apples
ginseng.description:
Ginseng is an entity-component-system (ECS) library designed for use in games.

The main advantage over similar libraries is that the component types do not need to be listed or registered. Component types are detected dynamically.

Any function-like object can be used as a system. The function's parameters are used to determine the required components.

mustache.name: mustache
mustache.author: @kirillochnev
mustache.description: A fast, modern C++ Entity Component System

openecs.name: OpenEcs
openecs.author: @Gronis
openecs.description: Open Ecs is an Entity Component System that uses metaprogramming, cache coherency, and other useful tricks to maximize performance and configurability. It is written in c++11 without further dependencies.

flecs.name: Flecs
flecs.author: @SanderMertens
flecs.description: Flecs is a fast and lightweight Entity Component System that lets you build games and simulations with millions of entities.

pico_ecs.name: pico_ecs
pico_ecs.author: @empyreanx
pico_ecs.description: A collection of cross-platform single header libraries written in C. Pure and simple ECS.

gaia-ecs.name: gaia-ecs
gaia-ecs.author: @richardbiely
gaia-ecs.description: Gaia-ECS is a fast and easy-to-use ECS framework.
